texts.definition: Predetermined negative effects that occur due randomness when trying a game action which don't occur during normal failures.
markups: <style="Definition">Predetermined negative effects that occur due randomness when trying a game action which don't occur during normal failures.</style>

Many games require the outcome of player actions to be determined by a combination of randomness and the diegetic skill of the agent the player is using to perform that action. <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style> are specifically bad results that occur randomly which have (bad) effects beyond those possible through ordinary failures.
TV Tropes have an entry for Critical Failure.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/H%C3%A2rnmaster">HÃ¢rnmaster</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Darkness">World of Darkness</link></style> games are examples of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> that make use of <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style>. Performing magic in both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Battle">Warhammer Fantasy Battle</link></style> has a certain risk of causing supernatural being to take notice to the action and react to it.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style> in a game have three main components: deciding which actions can result in <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style>, what the effects are of those failures, and what should be the probabilities of such failures. <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> is probably the most common case where <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style> are used through the most specific pattern <style="Link"><link="critical-misses">Critical Misses</link></style> but actions requiring the use of <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> are also common since these <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> allow easy ways to construct algorithms that decide the probabilities of <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style> (meaning that these two patterns modulate each other). The negative effects of <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style> can be described as simply attributing specific <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> to those suffering from them, but these <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> are typically ones that one cannot get through ordinary failures. As just mentioned, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> can be used to calculate the probabilities of <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style>, but these can also be modified by <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> in the case of <style="Link"><link="critical-misses">Critical Misses</link></style>). Regardless of how the probabilities are determined, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> needs to be used to create <style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style> since by definition the pattern does not depend directly on players' performances.

<style="CurrentLink">Critical Failures</style> are a type of <style="Link"><link="critical-results">Critical Results</link></style> and can become <style="Link"><link="exceptional-events">Exceptional Events</link></style>. Rather obviously, they are in conflict with <style="Link"><link="critical-successes">Critical Successes</link></style>, and make <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> less likely. Since they are based on <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> rather than how well players' perform, they also work against <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style>.
